Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis of Phostones via Phosphono Substituted Metal Allyl Intermediates
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Christopher D. Spilling of the University of Missouri St. Louis is developing new carbon-carbon bond forming reactions with applications in the synthesis of medicinally relevant phosphate-substituted sugars. The phosphate group is a fundamental component of all living systems, and is important for molecular replication, cell biochemistry, cell signalling pathways, and activation in metabolic processes. The research builds on prior phosphorous-based research developing new nickel-based processes to access important carbon scaffolds. The broader impact of this program lies in developing new tools for organic synthesis and the training of undergraduate and graduate students. A particular emphasis is placed on undergraduate participation in research to provide a solid training in the techniques of synthetic organic chemistry. The training will help provide skilled workers to support pharmaceutical research and related chemical industry in the US.

The intellectual merit is focused on developing synthetic methods based on new organophosphorous chemistry. Metal allyl intermediates derived from precursors such as epoxy-vinyl phosphonates, 1- and 2- substituted phosphono-1,3-dienes and phosphono allylic carbonates provide unique methods of stereoselective C-C and C-heteroatom bond forming reactions. These reactions allow complimentary approaches to the synthesis of phostones and phosphonosugars that have novel biological properties and may serve as lead compounds for medicinal chemistry. This de novo approach provides phostones with unique substitution patterns and stereochemistry which deviate from the readily available (common) carbohydrates that is ideally suited to the synthesis of potential antagonists of lipid A.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.

The importance of asymmetric carbon-carbon bond forming reactions in synthesis and the role of phosphonates in biochemistry as active analogs of important phosphate biomolecules cannot be overstated. This project has focused on the development of asymmetric C-C bond forming reactions using phosphonate reagents and the application of these reactions in the synthesis of the phosphorus containing chemical entities called phostones, phosphonosugars, and related deoxyribose C-nucleosides/glycoside analogs. There were three major successes to this end.

We discovered a new and efficient synthesis of phostones (cyclic phosphonates) based on the chemistry of g,d-epoxy-vinyl phosphonates.

We discovered a new route to deoxyribose C-nucleoside/glycoside analogs employing the Mori-Tamaru reaction of phosphono substituted dienes (diene+aldehyde with catalytic Ni(acac)2 and Et3Al). Deoxyribose C-nucleosides/glycoside are structures often associated with anti-tumor and anti-viral activity.

We have shown that simple sugar molecules in which the anomeric carbon is replaced by a methylene phosphonate. (phosphonosugars) or a lactone display antagonistic properties toward Lipid A. Lipid A is a polyacyl disaccharide component of lipidpolysaccharide and the causative agent in sepsis. Compounds which block this activity are called antagonists and can help stop sepsis.

 

Broader Impact of Activity.

The chemistry describe above allows rapid and efficient access to compounds with unique and interesting structures. We recently received funding from the UM system with a team of colleagues to develop compounds active against sepsis (Lipid A antagonists). We will employ much of the chemistry developed in this NSF funded project to prepare a three unique series of compounds towards this goal; phostones and 5 and 6 membered phosphonosugars with unique substitution patterns and stereochemistry.

An important aspect of this research program is the training of undergraduate and graduate students. The students working on these projects receive a solid training in the research methods and techniques of synthetic organic chemistry. In all, 10 students contributed to this project resulting in 3 MS degrees, 4 BS degrees and 1 BA degree so far. Two students (1 MS and 1 BS) have gone on to medical school and one (BA) to pharmacy school. Three students entered the chemical industry and one of them has enrolled in graduate programs at UMSL. Unusually, one student commissioned into the US Navy via Officer Candidate School (OCS). Three students are continuing on towards PhD degrees.

            While much of the work has yet to be published, the findings have been presented by the PI in invited talks at international meetings and universities and by the students in contributed talks and posters at national and regional meetings.

Modified by: Christopher D Spilling
